awd_titl_txt: RCN-UBE: CC Bio INSITES: Community College Biology Instructor Network to Support Inquiry into Teaching and Education Scholarship
awd_abstract_narration:
Biology education research (BER), where biology faculty investigate teaching and learning within their own discipline, is considered a vital tool for transforming undergraduate biology education and enhancing student success. However, even though approximately half of biology majors complete coursework at community colleges (CCs), including disproportionate numbers of under-served students, only 3% of recent BER papers included a CC author or CC study context. This raises concerns that existing BER may have failed to characterize the educational experiences of half of the relevant undergraduate population and that innovations stemming from BER might not be reaching CCs. This project is a grassroots effort driven by a strong nationwide group of CC faculty to promote, conduct, and publish CC BER. The network will mobilize diverse stakeholders from CC settings including students, faculty and administrators to journal editors and national society leaders to enhance the representation of CCs in BER. Grounded in the unique values and cultures of CCs, it will provide opportunities for intellectual support, infrastructure support, and social support to mitigate previously hypothesized constraints on CC BER and empower CC faculty to engage in and publish BER. The project will thus address the paucity of BER from CC contexts and contribute insights that can improve life science instruction for students from underserved groups across all institutional contexts. 

The intellectual merit of the project is to address research questions about the types of social, infrastructure and intellectual support CC BER. These networks will build on established models of change, provide answers to research questions regarding hypothesized constraints to CC BER, and integrate with existing networks. At the core of this national effort will be 20 geographically dispersed, regional CC BER networks. These regional networks, consisting of approximately five individuals representing CC faculty, administrators, students, future CC faculty, and CC BER advocates, will meet regularly and make substantial progress on one or more collaborative CC BER projects. The national network effort will provide intellectual resources in the form of faculty development experiences in BER at an opening national meeting, ongoing mentorship for regional networks, and travel to national BER conferences. Additionally, the network will provide critical resources often absent at CCs, such as access to an Institutional Review Board and journal articles. The project will culminate with presentations by regional teams at a national BER meeting and preparation of manuscripts related to regional efforts. As a result, the new CC BER network will make substantial, novel contributions to the present body of knowledge regarding CC biology teaching and learning and will provide insights into how networks can support innovation at CCs and in education research broadly.

This project is being jointly funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education as part of their efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Biology Education: A Call to Action (http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/).

por.por_cntn:
Almost half of all undergraduates nationally attend community colleges (CCs), which enroll the majority of all Latina/o, Native American, and Black undergraduates, and large proportions of low-income and first-generation students (AACC, 2016, 2023). Because the first two years of college are considered “the most critical to the retention and recruitment of STEM majors” and because such a large proportion of students – particularly those from underserved backgrounds – receive that initial training at CCs, CCs have been broadly recognized for their potential to influence early undergraduate learning in STEM. Despite this growing interest and an understanding that biology education research (BER) plays a key role in efforts to transform biology education (AAAS, 2011; Offerdahl et al., 2011; PCAST, 2012), there is a paucity of biology education articles that feature CC authors or context. In 2017 at the start of this grant, only approximately three percent of BER articles featured CC authors or study contexts (Schinske et al., 2017). This raises serious concerns about 1. whether BER offers a representative view of teaching and learning in higher education, given that the institutions serving nearly half of undergraduates are largely unexamined, and 2. the extent to which CCs are included in evidence-based student success initiatives explored in BER.

In 2017, CC Bio INSITES or the Community College Biology Instructor Network to Support Inquiry into Teaching and Education Scholarship, set out with the intention of addressing this challenge and aimed to increase the number of studies and publications addressing CC contexts. CC Bio INSITES enhanced CC faculty engagement in BER through regional, national and virtual networking. The facilitators of the network specifically provided participants with the resources (e.g., funds for travel and to do research) they would need to engage, intellectual support to learn the skills and tools they might need, and social support to provide encouragement, inspiration, community, and connection to their peers and others within the broader BER community. Annual in-person meetings in addition to virtual synchronous and asynchronous work provided the support needed for INSITES members. 

These efforts have resulted in substantial, tangible advancements in the CC BER landscape. CC Bio INSITES has contributed to a doubling of the prevalence of CC BER among BER publications when comparing 2012-2017 (prior to the network) to 2018-2023. 12 peer reviewed articles have been published as a direct result of CC Bio INSITES participant collaborations, and more are expected. Many more articles have been published by non-INSITES authors but have been inspired by INSITES work and members’ leadership. There have been new investments in CCs and CC BER by prominent funding agencies that have been, in part, spurred by INSITES efforts and leadership of INSITES members. Professional societies and journals have been spurred by INSITES members’ efforts to express more concern regarding representation of CCs in national meetings, conferences, and publications. As a result, there have been new meeting sessions focused on CC BER and a special issue on CC BER in CBE - Life Sciences Education (LSE). Finally, the network has vastly expanded the power and influence of CC faculty within the BER community. INSITES members have accessed numerous leadership roles in which they are actively making change and inspiring new research. Members are now serving as administrators within their own institutions, journal editorial board members, leaders of professional development programs, and leaders within national societies. Taken together, these results demonstrate the broad success of the network as a whole in the area of increasing CC faculty engagement in BER. 

CC Bio INSITES additionally spearheaded and evaluated novel strategies for building a community of faculty to engage in a new (to them) field of research. Outcomes for individual participants in the network demonstrated that the provision of social support, above and beyond intellectual or resources support, helped them feel a sense of belonging to the community and inspired their continued engagement. Likewise, continued engagement, intellectual support, and social support contributed to increases in participants’ sense of self-efficacy when conducting BER and their belonging to the broader BER community. These results are detailed in two research publications investigating network outcomes published in LSE. The INSITES model of providing, first and foremost, social support alongside resource and intellectual support is a promising approach as we aim to increase the diversity of researchers within the field of BER.
